title: HL-93 Live Load Moment for Simple Span
problem: Calculate the unfactored live load moment for the Strength I limit state for an interior girder of a simple span bridge. The span length is 85 feet, and the girder spacing is 8.5 feet. Use the HL-93 loading with appropriate distribution factors.
given: Design load: HL-93 (Design Truck + Design Lane + Design Tandem)
Composite concrete deck on steel girder
required: Calculate the unfactored HL-93 live load moment at midspan for an interior girder.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Truck Moment
solution_steps.content: For HL-93 Design Truck (3-axle truck): Axle loads = 8 kips, 32 kips, 32 kips. Axle spacings: 14 ft variable (between front and first rear), 14 ft (between rear axles). For maximum moment on simple span, place truck to maximize midspan moment. Critical position: Heaviest axles near midspan. Using influence lines or standard formulas: For L = 85 ft with design truck positioned optimally: M_truck ≈ 32 × (L/4 - L²/4×14/L) + 32 × L/4 + 8 × (L/4 - 14). Actually, using standard formula: M_truck = 72L - 288 for L ≥ 40 ft (approximately). For L = 85 ft: M_truck ≈ 72(85) - 288 = 5,832 kip-ft. More precisely using structural analysis: M_truck = 1,298 kip-ft (single lane, per AASHTO tables). Actually, calculate exactly: Place rear axle at 14/2 = 7 ft from midspan. M_truck ≈ 1,350 kip-ft (approximate for 85 ft span).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Lane Load Moment
solution_steps.content: Design Lane Load = 0.64 klf uniformly distributed. For simple span, maximum moment at midspan: M_lane = wL²/8 = 0.64 × (85)²/8 = 0.64 × 7,225/8 = 578 kip-ft.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Tandem Moment
solution_steps.content: Design Tandem = Two 25-kip axles, 4 ft apart. For simple span, critical position: Place center of tandem at midspan. M_tandem = 25 × (L/2 - 2) × (L/2) / L + 25 × (L/2 + 2) × (L/2) / L. M_tandem = 25 × (42.5 - 2) × 42.5/85 + 25 × (42.5 + 2) × 42.5/85. M_tandem = 25 × 20.3 + 25 × 22.3 = 507 + 558 = 1,065 kip-ft.

solution_steps.title: Combine HL-93 Load Effects
solution_steps.content: Per AASHTO LRFD Article 3.6.1.2, HL-93 is the larger of: (1) Design Truck + Lane, or (2) Design Tandem + Lane. Case 1: M_HL-93 = M_truck + M_lane = 1,350 + 578 = 1,928 kip-ft. Case 2: M_HL-93 = M_tandem + M_lane = 1,065 + 578 = 1,643 kip-ft. Controlling: Case 1 with Design Truck. M_HL-93 = 1,928 kip-ft (single lane, per lane).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Live Load Distribution Factor
solution_steps.content: Per AASHTO LRFD Article 4.6.2.2.2, for interior beam with concrete deck on steel beam. Type (a) - Concrete Deck on Steel I-Beam: Distribution factor for moment (one design lane loaded): g1 = 0.06 + (S/14)⁰·⁴ × (S/L)⁰·³ × (Kg/12.0L·t³s)⁰·¹. Where S = 8.5 ft, L = 85 ft, ts = 8 in = 0.67 ft. Kg = n(I + Aec²) (longitudinal stiffness parameter). For simplified calculation, use approximate formulas: g1 = S/5.5 = 8.5/5.5 = 1.55 (approximate for one lane). More precisely from Table 4.6.2.2.2b-1: g1 = 0.06 + (8.5/14)⁰·⁴ × (8.5/85)⁰·³ × (12Lts³/...)⁰·¹. Simplified: g1 ≈ 0.40 for one lane loaded (typical). For two or more lanes: g2 ≈ 0.55.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Live Load Moment per Girder
solution_steps.content: Using distribution factor for multiple lanes loaded (conservative for design): g = 0.55. M_LL = M_HL-93 × g = 1,928 × 0.55 = 1,060 kip-ft. Include dynamic load allowance (impact factor) IM = 33% for truck and tandem loads only: M_LL+IM = (M_truck × 1.33 + M_lane) × g. M_LL+IM = (1,350 × 1.33 + 578) × 0.55 = (1,796 + 578) × 0.55 = 2,374 × 0.55 = 1,306 kip-ft.

final_answer: The unfactored HL-93 live load moment for the interior girder is M_LL+IM = 1,306 kip-ft. This includes the truck moment with 33% impact plus lane load, distributed using g = 0.55. For Strength I limit state, apply load factor γLL = 1.75.

title: Load Rating of Existing Bridge Girder
problem: Evaluate the load rating of a prestressed concrete I-girder in an existing bridge. The girder has a nominal flexural capacity of Mn = 8,500 kip-ft. The dead load moment from DC (structural components) is 1,200 kip-ft and from DW (wearing surface) is 350 kip-ft. The live load moment from HL-93 including distribution and impact is 1,850 kip-ft. Determine the Inventory and Operating load rating factors.
given: Live load moment (HL-93 with impact) M_LL+IM = 1,850 kip-ft
required: Calculate the Inventory Rating Factor (RF) and Operating Rating Factor.

solution_steps.title: Determine Resistance Factor and Capacity
solution_steps.content: Per AASHTO LRFD Article 5.5.4.2, for prestressed concrete in flexure: φ = 1.0 (tension-controlled, as typical for prestressed members). Factored resistance: RF = φMn = 1.0 × 8,500 = 8,500 kip-ft.

solution_steps.title: Determine Load Factors for Inventory Rating
solution_steps.content: Per AASHTO MBE Article 6A.4.2.1 for Strength I limit state (Inventory): γDC = 1.25, γDW = 1.50, γLL = 1.75.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Inventory Rating Factor
solution_steps.content: Using the general rating equation: RF = (φMn - γDC × MDC - γDW × MDW) / (γLL × M_LL+IM). RF_Inventory = (8,500 - 1.25 × 1,200 - 1.50 × 350) / (1.75 × 1,850). Numerator = 8,500 - 1,500 - 525 = 6,475 kip-ft. Denominator = 1.75 × 1,850 = 3,238 kip-ft. RF_Inventory = 6,475 / 3,238 = 2.00.

solution_steps.title: Determine Load Factors for Operating Rating
solution_steps.content: Per AASHTO MBE Article 6A.4.2.2 for Strength I limit state (Operating): γDC = 1.25, γDW = 1.50, γLL = 1.35.

solution_steps.title: Interpret Results
solution_steps.content: The rating factors indicate the bridge can carry loads greater than HL-93. RF_Inventory = 2.00 means the bridge can carry 200% of HL-93 loading at inventory level (infinite passes). RF_Operating = 2.59 means the bridge can carry 259% of HL-93 loading at operating level (limited passes). Both ratings exceed 1.0, indicating the girder is adequate.

final_answer: Inventory Rating Factor = 2.00, Operating Rating Factor = 2.59. Both values exceed 1.0, indicating the prestressed concrete girder has adequate capacity for HL-93 loading. The bridge can safely carry 200% of HL-93 design load at inventory level.

title: Composite Steel Girder Section Properties
problem: A composite steel girder bridge uses a W36×182 steel beam with an 8-inch thick concrete deck. The effective flange width is 7.5 feet. Calculate the section properties for the composite section in positive flexure. Use f'c = 4,500 psi for the deck. Determine the composite moment of inertia for short-term loads (n = 8).
given: Effective flange width be = 7.5 ft = 90 in
required: Calculate the composite section moment of inertia for short-term loads.

solution_steps.title: Determine Steel Section Properties
solution_steps.content: From AISC Manual for W36×182: A = 53.6 in², d = 36.3 in, bf = 12.1 in, tf = 0.96 in, tw = 0.56 in, Ix = 12,100 in⁴. The neutral axis of the steel section is at mid-height: ysteel_NA = d/2 = 18.15 in from bottom.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Transformed Concrete Area
solution_steps.content: Transform concrete deck to equivalent steel area using modular ratio n = 8: b_transformed = be/n = 90/8 = 11.25 in. Transformed concrete area: Ac_trans = b_transformed × ts = 11.25 × 8 = 90 in².

solution_steps.title: Locate Composite Neutral Axis
solution_steps.content: Define y as distance from bottom of steel girder to composite neutral axis. Take moments about bottom of steel girder: Ac_trans × (d + ts/2) + As × ysteel_NA = (Ac_trans + As) × y. 90 × (36.3 + 4) + 53.6 × 18.15 = (90 + 53.6) × y. 90 × 40.3 + 973 = 143.6 × y. 3,627 + 973 = 143.6 × y. y = 4,600/143.6 = 32.0 in from bottom of steel girder.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Composite Moment of Inertia
solution_steps.content: I_comp = I_steel + As × (y - ysteel_NA)² + Ac_trans × (d + ts/2 - y)² + I_deck_trans. I_steel = 12,100 in⁴. As × (32.0 - 18.15)² = 53.6 × (13.85)² = 53.6 × 192 = 10,291 in⁴. Ac_trans × (40.3 - 32.0)² = 90 × (8.3)² = 90 × 69 = 6,210 in⁴. I_deck_trans about its own NA = b_trans × ts³/12 = 11.25 × 512/12 = 480 in⁴. I_comp = 12,100 + 10,291 + 6,210 + 480 = 29,081 in⁴.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Section Moduli
solution_steps.content: Section modulus to bottom flange: S_bottom = I_comp/y = 29,081/32.0 = 909 in³. Section modulus to top of concrete deck: S_deck = I_comp/(d + ts - y) = 29,081/(36.3 + 8 - 32.0) = 29,081/12.3 = 2,365 in³. Section modulus to top of steel: S_top_steel = I_comp/(d - y) = 29,081/(36.3 - 32.0) = 29,081/4.3 = 6,765 in³.

final_answer: The composite section moment of inertia for short-term loads is I_comp = 29,100 in⁴ (rounded). The neutral axis is located 32.0 inches from the bottom of the steel girder. The composite section modulus to the bottom flange is S = 909 in³, which is significantly larger than the non-composite Sx = 667 in³.

title: Prestressed Girder Stress Check at Transfer
problem: A prestressed concrete I-girder has a cross-sectional area A = 789 in², section modulus to bottom Sb = 14,520 in³, and section modulus to top St = 7,850 in³. The girder self-weight moment at midspan is 650 kip-ft. The initial prestress force after immediate losses is Pi = 1,120 kips with an eccentricity e = 18 inches. Check the concrete stresses at midspan at transfer. Use f'ci = 5,000 psi (concrete strength at transfer).
given: Section modulus to bottom Sb = 14,520 in³
Section modulus to top St = 7,850 in³
Concrete strength at transfer f'ci = 5,000 psi
required: Check concrete stresses at midspan at transfer against allowable limits.

solution_steps.title: Determine Allowable Stresses at Transfer
solution_steps.content: Per AASHTO LRFD Article 5.9.4.1.2, at transfer: Compression: f_allow_comp = 0.60f'ci = 0.60 × 5,000 = 3,000 psi. Tension: f_allow_tens = 0.24√f'ci = 0.24√5000 = 17 psi (without bonded reinforcement). With adequate bonded reinforcement: f_allow_tens = 0.58√f'ci = 41 psi (but typically limited to 200 psi for practical design). Actually, per AASHTO: In precompressed tensile zone, tension is limited to 200 psi maximum, otherwise 0.0948√f'ci = 6.7 psi.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Stress Due to Prestress
solution_steps.content: Axial stress from prestress: f_axial = Pi/A = 1,120,000/789 = 1,420 psi (compression). Bending stress from prestress eccentricity: f_bending = Pi×e/S. At bottom fiber: f_bend_bot = 1,120,000 × 18 / 14,520 = 1,389 psi (tension if positive moment causes compression at bottom). Wait, for prestress with eccentricity below centroid: At bottom: f_p_bot = Pi/A + Pi×e/Sb = 1,420 + 1,389 = 2,809 psi (compression). At top: f_p_top = Pi/A - Pi×e/St = 1,420 - (1,120,000×18/7,850) = 1,420 - 2,568 = -1,148 psi (tension).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Stress Due to Self-Weight
solution_steps.content: Self-weight moment Mg = 650 kip-ft = 7,800 kip-in. At bottom fiber: f_g_bot = Mg/Sb = 7,800,000/14,520 = 537 psi (tension). At top fiber: f_g_top = -Mg/St = -7,800,000/7,850 = -994 psi (compression).

solution_steps.title: Calculate Combined Stresses at Transfer
solution_steps.content: At bottom fiber: f_bot = f_p_bot + f_g_bot = -2,809 + 537 = -2,272 psi (compression). At top fiber: f_top = f_p_top + f_g_top = -1,148 + (-994) = 1,148 + 994 = wait, sign convention... f_top = f_p_top + f_g_top = (-1,148) + (-994) = -2,142 psi (both tension, should be wrong). Let me recalculate: Prestress eccentricity causes upward camber (negative moment). So prestress moment = -Pi×e. At top: f_p_top = Pi/A - (Pi×e)/St = 1,420 - (1,120×18/7.85) = 1,420 - 2,568 = -1,148 psi (tension, correct). Self-weight causes downward deflection (positive moment). At top: compression. Combined: f_top = -1,148 + 994 = -154 psi (tension).

solution_steps.title: Compare to Allowable Stresses
solution_steps.content: Bottom fiber: f_bot = 2,272 psi (compression). Allowable = 3,000 psi. f_bot < f_allow ✓. Top fiber: f_top = 154 psi (tension). Allowable tension in precompressed zone = 200 psi (with bonded reinforcement). f_top < 200 psi ✓. Both stresses are within allowable limits at transfer.

solution_steps.title: Check if Bonded Reinforcement Required
solution_steps.content: Since tension at top (154 psi) exceeds 0.24√f'ci = 17 psi, bonded reinforcement is required in the tensile zone. The area of reinforcement should be calculated per AASHTO Article 5.9.4.1.2. As_required = (T_tension)/fy where T_tension = f_top × (affected area).

final_answer: At transfer, the concrete stresses are: Bottom fiber = 2,272 psi compression (allowable = 3,000 psi) ✓. Top fiber = 154 psi tension (allowable = 200 psi with bonded reinforcement) ✓. Both stresses are within limits, but bonded reinforcement is required in the top flange since tension exceeds 0.24√f'ci = 17 psi.
